Award.AwardTitle: Workshop: Women of Color in Political Science 2019: August 2019 - Washington, D.C.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research demonstrates that women of color face barriers such as lack of mentorship, financial resources, and significant familial responsibilities in their pursuit of higher education and subsequent careers in political science. Political science is one of the most male and Anglo dominated fields of study in the social sciences. Descriptive representation within the academic profession is important to perceptions of legitimacy, service to students, and development of knowledge. The goal of the conference is to provide attendees the necessary skills and networks to enter the academy, successfully achieve tenure and sustain their careers thereafter. This workshop brings together scholars from different universities, at different stages in their careers, to deepen intellectual engagement and to build coalitions that support excellence in diversifying the political science profession.

This workshop brings together scholars from different universities, at different stages in their careers, to deepen intellectual engagement and to build coalitions that support excellence in diversifying the political science profession. The workshop includes an opening plenary session that focuses on the development of intersectionality work in the discipline and a discussion of the discipline and the role of women of color therein. It also includes a series of breakout sessions that focus on various aspects of academic development. The workshop will facilitate deep mentoring by pairing graduate students, junior, and mid-career participants by interest, with structured one-on-one mentoring time embedded into the schedule.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2019 Workshop on Women of Color in Political Science was held at the R.I.S.E. Demonstration Center in Washington, DC on August 28, 2019. In attendance were 65 graduate students, junior faculty, senior faculty, and administrators. Workshop content addressed how to write and publish op-eds, how to produce and publish scholarship, and how to negotiate the unique challenges faced by women of color in academia, among other topics. Building on the success of and feedback from workshops held in 2002, 2013, 2015, and 2017, the 2019 event delivered content aimed at cultivating the academic success of participants and mitigating the leaky pipeline, to the benefit of participants, their institutions, the discipline, and the public at large.

Political science is one of the most male and white dominated fields of study in the social sciences. Increased diversity has eluded the discipline not because women students of color are not interested in political science, but because a) at some point they drop out of the pipeline, and b) they face significant barriers to professional advancement and success after achieving their PhDs. Women of color face barriers such as lack of mentorship, financial resources, and significant familial responsibilities in their pursuit of higher education and subsequent careers. Plugging the leaks in the pipeline and building a discipline that is not only more representative but also equitable and inclusive requires commitment of time and resources to cultivate the success of those women throughout their graduate school educations and tenure. Losing those women is a loss not just for those individuals, but for the discipline and for society; who knows how much valuable research is being lost when these women decide to leave political science. Cultivating a culture that supports the retention and success of women of color benefits everyone.

Our workshop cultivates that culture across the discipline of political science, bringing participants together to form strong mutual mentoring networks. The workshop developed a community of support, allowing more junior scholars to see that the challenges they face are not unique. Paired with the stories shared by senior women of color at our workshop, this helps more junior scholars see a path to success.

Evidence of the effectiveness of the workshop comes from the pre- and post-event surveys completed by participants, as well as from post-workshop focus groups. Women of color come away from the day with a stronger network and with a realization that the challenges they face are endemic to the discipline, not a result of any individual factors unique to themselves or their own situations. They also come away with stronger levels of confidence in their skills to succeed in the profession.

Academia in general and the discipline of political science specifically are environments where women of color are both invisible and tokenized -- valued for the diversity they represent but also marginalized and unsupported. Our biennial workshops provide participants with the mentoring and networking skills to help them survive and thrive.
